channel.title: Visual Basic to ...?
channel.description:
Hey MoparScape,
I'm used to coding RSPS, I've done a few little things in Visual Basic. But VB, is kind of pathetic if you want to actually learn. What is a program to download like and IDE I can use to start creating programs from scratch, I'm got no Idea of a program name let alone how to code and the way of coding in an IDE. Please post back and maybe link me to a few tutorials of something.
Thanks,
Skyro. ;)

item.title: Visual Basic to ...?
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“lemme_winks_, post:13, topic:434644”][quote author=_s link=topic=537359.msg3929330#msg3929330 date=1330537941]

notepad++, gedit, vim, nano are all lightweight text editors with syntax highlighting.

emacs
[/quote]sublime text 2

sublime and emacs - emacs will win.[/quote]well yeah

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic to ...?
item.dc:creator: @Sunder Sunder
item.description:
@Sunder wrote:

I suggest you get a book on Java, C++, C, or C#. If your goal is to actually learn a language and not just copypasta and drag-drop controls, then you should get a book and go through it, doing all the exercises. You shouldn’t really bother with Visual Basic, it’s typically seen as a script kiddie language and if you tell a C++ programmer “Hey, I’m a Visual Basic programmer.” or something along those lines, they might laugh at you. If you must use .NET and Visual Studio, use C#. C# is very similar to Java anyway.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic to ...?
item.dc:creator: @Agent766 Agent766
item.description:
@Agent766 wrote:

Start looking for tutorials. Stick with a proven IDE like Eclipse. You need to identify what your goal is, what you’re trying to do. If you’re trying to learn new algorithms, Project Euler is the best place to do that.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic to ...?
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Well in the poll… I don’t know why “Notepad” is up there because it’s not a programming language like the other options. Depending on what language you want to learn, there are hundreds of online resources. If you are going with Java like you said, then go to http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/, or possibly http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,66248.0.html for a list of a lot of resources compiled by the community.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic to ...?
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Skyro, post:5, topic:434644”][quote author=vManlyMan link=topic=537359.msg3929165#msg3929165 date=1330514392]
Then stick with Java and expand your boundaries past RSPS.

As for IDE’s:

eclipse.org

The Platform for Open Innovation and Collaboration | The Eclipse Foundation

The Eclipse Foundation - home to a global community, the Eclipse IDE, Jakarta EE and over 350 open source projects, including runtimes, tools and frameworks.


www.netbeans.org
[/quote]
I was always sticking with Java, sorry for not saying. I also have eclipse.[/quote]

Well you clearly don’t know enough. Keep at it.

Read full topic

But for writing scripts & websites I personally prefer Notepad++, I’d download that if you haven’t already got it.
